text: the front-runner in the contest to
succeed Theresa May as Prime Minister
the former foreign secretary Boris
Johnson has been told by a judge that he
will face a court case over accusations
of misconduct in public office the case
centers on claims that he lied during
the brexit referendum campaign about the
amount of money the UK paid to the EU
let's get more on this with our news
correspondent Andy Moore who's following
this for us and Andy this stems from a
crowdfunded campaign that's why crowd
funded to the tune of about two hundred
thousand pounds a Norfolk businessman
Marcus ball went to magistrate's court
and argued before a judge there that
this was such a serious offense of lying
by a very senior politician er was such
a major issue that it represented
misconduct in public office which is a
very serious criminal offense so this
was an important stage along the way
today the judge judge Coleman said she
wasn't making any decision about the
facts the case was unproven but she said
there was a case to answer so she's
sending it on to the next stage so that
means that mr. Johnston will have to
appear personally at Westminster
magistrates court to face three charges
of misconduct in public office
basically the same offence over
different time scales and then it will
go to a Crown Court because it is such a
serious issue that carries possibly if
found guilty more than a six-month jail
sentence do we have a date for that that
next court appearance no we don't have a
date for that
okay I'm wondering just in the context
obviously of the conservative leadership
election and when that might happen
has mr. Johnson said anything about this
since we last spoke when the story was
breaking an hour ago
we've not heard from mr. Johnson himself
we know what his view really is from the
argument put forward by his lawyers of
the previous hearing and they said this
was basically a political stunt brought
by anti-breakage campaigners that
politicians you know in the
rough-and-tumble of a campaign are free
to make claims and they will be
held their feet to the fire by other
politicians and their be challenged on
them I mean one politician David Miller
has said it's ridiculous if a politician
it's going to face possibly a criminal
charge for every time they're accused of
lying he says this is just nuts and that
senior judges will be holding their
heads in wonder what a junior judge has
decided hmm okay very interesting Andy
thank you very much well let's get more
in this with our assistant political
editor Norman Smith in Westminster so
Norman what could this mean for mr.
Johnson's leadership campaign well the
first thing you have to say is the
timing could hardly be more damaging
given that we are now in a leadership
campaign in which mr. Johnson is widely
seen as the favorite and yet even before
he's got out the blocks to formally
launch his campaign set up his ideas the
headlines are all going to be about the
fact he's now facing a court case with
at the end of the day a potential prison
sentence
the second thing obviously about it is
the massive distraction it is for team
Johnson here they are trying to hone
their message and yet they are now going
to have to spend quite a bit of time I
would imagine trying to dampen down this
story and come up with a credible report
to it and it does open up really the
extraordinary potential juxtaposition of
mr. mr. Johnson appearing in court and
he himself will have to appear in court
appearing in court at precisely the same
time as he is appealing to yes the Tory
party but also the nation to trust him
to become the next prime minister and
both those processes will be going on at
precisely the same time and the last
thing which seems to me is inevitably it
will be used by his critics and I expect
will reignite the question marks about
the character question about mr.
Johnson's character because we know
throughout his political career he has
you know faced all sorts of scrapes and
the criticism has come you know from his
own side Michael Howard sacked him
Michael Gove who was leading his
leadership campaign last time decided
that he just didn't think he was a fit
person and in effect brought his
campaign to an end by saying he could
not support him it seems to me that
although this is you know just a summons
it's not a verdict
the simple fact this case is now going
ahead will reignite those character
questions and will be used by mr.
Johnson's critics and I guess more
broadly Norman politicians will look at
this and consider that you know if a
private individual wants to crowdfund a
case against an MP you know then it can
lead to court like this one is well I'm
sure mr. Johnson's allies and we've yet
to hear from his team I think they will
be issuing a statement but are just
looking at the sort of the legal
parameters of what they can say I'm sure
there's around mr. Johnson will just say
well this is you know just people who
are bitterly opposed to the Brexton
referendum seem to cause as much damage
as possible indeed if you look at the
the court papers the judge actually
points out that mr. Johnson's team
argued that this case was being brought
to secure as much publicity as possible
presumably to damage the case what
breaks it down to damage mr. Johnson now
he ruled that there was a case to answer
and that the allegations were not
vexatious but I suspect there will be
quite a few people at Westminster who
think well you know this is the cut and
thrust of politics and if you're going
to force politicians to potentially face
legal action for every set of statistics
they use then you are really going to
severely constrain political argument
okay Norman thank you very much for that
Norman Smith
